entity1.name: Human Cloning
entity1.description: A scientific process that creates a genetic copy of an organism, specifically a human in this context.;;;A scientific technique to create a genetic copy of a human being.;;;A process of creating a genetic replica of an existing individual.;;;A process of creating a genetically identical copy of a human being.;;;A process of creating a genetic copy of a human being.;;;A biological process involving the creation of organisms that are genetically identical to another organism.;;;The process of transferring an organ from one body to another for the purpose of replacing a damaged or diseased organ.;;;A technique used to create a genetically identical copy of an organism or cells.;;;An organism that is genetically identical to another, created through cloning techniques.;;;A process of creating a genetic copy of a human being, often discussed in the context of medical research and ethical debates.;;;A process used to create genetically identical copies of organisms.;;;A technique in biotechnology for creating a copy of an organism or its genetic material.;;;A scientific method that involves creating a genetically identical copy of an organism or biological material.;;;A scientific process that creates a genetic copy of a human being.;;;A scientific method that involves creating a genetically identical copy of an organism.;;;A scientific technique to create a genetic copy of an existing organism, in this case, humans.;;;The process of creating a genetically identical copy of an organism, often used in scientific and medical contexts.
entity1.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning1;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning2;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning15;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning14;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning21;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning7;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning3;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning12;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning4;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning8;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning5;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning20;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning10;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning16;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning11;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning22;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning13;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning6;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning17

entity2.name: Ethical Questions
entity2.description: Questions concerning the moral principles and values related to human cloning, including issues of identity, life sanctity, and genetic manipulation consequences.;;;The branch of philosophy that involves systematizing, defending, and recommending concepts of right and wrong behavior.;;;A principle that emphasizes the inherent value and inviolability of human life, often invoked in debates about bioethics.;;;Issues related to the ethical implications and spiritual significance of certain actions or technologies, such as human cloning.
entity2.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning1;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning12;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning20

entity4.name: scientists
entity4.description: Scientists or scholars engaged in systematic investigation to discover new knowledge or develop new theories and technologies.;;;Professionals engaged in scientific research and experimentation.
entity4.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning16;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning2

entity5.name: policymakers
entity5.description: Individuals or groups responsible for creating, developing, and implementing policies and laws.

entity6.name: general public
entity6.description: The population at large, not limited to any specific group or profession.

entity9.name: individuality and personal identity
entity9.description: The characteristics or qualities that constitute an individual's unique self, including their sense of self and continuity over time.

entity12.name: Critics
entity12.description: A collective term for individuals who express disapproval or criticism, in this case regarding the practice of cloning.

entity15.name: identical twins
entity15.description: Individuals who develop from a single fertilized egg and therefore share the same genetic makeup but can have different experiences and identities.

entity17.name: humans
entity17.description: The human species, Homo sapiens, characterized by the capacity for complex thought and culture.;;;Refers to the human species, Homo sapiens.
entity17.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning9;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning13

entity18.name: designer babies
entity18.description: A term used to describe the hypothetical practice of genetically modifying embryos to select for desired traits before implantation in a womb.

entity19.name: unethical experiments
entity19.description: Refers to scientific or medical experiments that violate ethical standards and principles, often causing harm or distress to subjects.

entity20.name: organ harvesting
entity20.description: The process of surgically removing organs from a donor's body for the purpose of transplanting them into another person who needs them.

entity22.name: genetically identical soldiers
entity22.description: Theoretical individuals with the same genetic makeup, potentially created through cloning for military purposes.

entity23.name: deceased individuals
entity23.description: People who have died and are no longer living.

entity28.name: religious traditions
entity28.description: Belief systems and practices followed by various groups that may include specific views on the natural order and human actions such as cloning.

entity31.name: divine
entity31.description: Refers to a supernatural being or power considered sacred or holy in religious contexts.

entity32.name: morality
entity32.description: The principles concerning the distinction between right and wrong or good and bad behavior.

entity33.name: spirituality
entity33.description: A broad concept that can involve a sense of connection to something greater than oneself, often associated with religious beliefs or practices.

entity35.name: medicine
entity35.description: The science and practice of the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease.;;;The systematic investigation into and study of materials, sources, and entities to establish facts and reach new conclusions in the field of medicine.
entity35.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning14;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning17

entity36.name: healthcare
entity36.description: The maintenance or improvement of health via the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease, illness, injury, and other physical and mental impairments in people.;;;The maintenance and improvement of physical and mental health, especially through the provision of medical services.
entity36.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning14;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning16

entity38.name: Stem cells
entity38.description: Undifferentiated cells capable of developing into various specialized cell types in the body.

entity39.name: Regenerative therapies
entity39.description: The process of providing medical care to improve health or manage disease conditions.;;;Therapies that aim to regenerate damaged or diseased tissues and organs, often using stem cells or other biological materials.
entity39.chunkid: The Ethics of Human Cloning15;;;The Ethics of Human Cloning17

entity41.name: Genetic diseases
entity41.description: Diseases caused by abnormalities in an individual's genome, which can be inherited or occur spontaneously.

entity42.name: Targeted treatments
entity42.description: Therapies designed to specifically target the mechanisms of a disease, often based on genetic or molecular profiles.

entity44.name: medical purposes
entity44.description: The use of medical treatments, procedures, and technologies for the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of diseases and other health conditions.

entity52.name: scientific inquiry
entity52.description: A systematic process used to investigate phenomena, acquire new knowledge, or correct and integrate previous knowledge.

entity54.name: medical progress
entity54.description: Advancements and improvements in the field of medicine and healthcare.

entity55.name: scientific discovery
entity55.description: New findings or knowledge gained through scientific research and experimentation.

entity57.name: principles of respect, integrity, and compassion
entity57.description: Core values guiding ethical behavior in research and innovation, emphasizing the importance of treating all individuals with dignity, honesty, and empathy.

entity58.name: knowledge and innovation
entity58.description: The pursuit of new information and creative ideas that drive progress in science and technology.
